## Understanding the meaning of words

- Linguistic systems:

--

  - word co-occurrence
  
  - word association

--

- Embodied systems:

--

  - perceptual

  - motor

  - emotional

  - social

---

## Research question

How are the linguistic and the visual bases of conceptual processing manifested at the levels of participants, words and tasks?

--

- Three studies with large samples

  - semantic priming (Hutchison et al., 2013)
 
  - semantic decision (Pexman et al., 2017)

  - lexical decision (Balota et al., 2007)
 
--

- A-priori power analysis for each study

---

#### Main individual differences

  - vocabulary size
  
--

#### Main word-level variables

  - corpus-based linguistic measure in each study
  
  - visual strength (Lynott et al., 2020)
  
---

### Why vision?

Other studies have considered more perceptual modalities, such as hearing, touch, taste and smell (e.g., Bernabeu et al., 2017).

Vision most prominent in the brain (Reilly et al., 2020) and in language (Lynott et al., 2020; Winter et al., 2018).

Individual differences in vision easiest to measure (not present in these studies but planned for next study).

---

### Statistical analysis

#### Lexical covariates

- All possible lexical covariates out of 5 typical candidates: 

  - Largest contributors without multicollinearity (*r* < .70) selected
    
#### Other important covariates for participant-level and word-level variables

- Word concreteness, fluid intelligence

---

## Semantic priming

### Primary data set: Hutchison et al. (2013)

```{r}

# Save number of participants and target_words
semanticpriming_number_participants = length(unique(semanticpriming$Participant))
semanticpriming_number_target_words = length(unique(semanticpriming$target_word))

# Number of target_words per participant
# Save mean as integer and SD rounded while keeping trailing zeros
semanticpriming_mean_target_words_per_participant = 
  semanticpriming %>% group_by(Participant) %>% 
  summarise(length(unique(target_word))) %>% 
  select(2) %>% unlist %>% mean %>% round(0)

semanticpriming_SD_target_words_per_participant = 
  semanticpriming %>% group_by(Participant) %>% 
  summarise(length(unique(target_word))) %>% 
  select(2) %>% unlist %>% sd %>% sprintf('%.2f', .)

# Number of participants per target_word
# Save mean as integer and SD rounded while keeping trailing zeros
semanticpriming_mean_participants_per_target_word = 
  semanticpriming %>% group_by(target_word) %>% 
  summarise(length(unique(Participant))) %>% 
  select(2) %>% unlist %>% mean %>% round(0)

semanticpriming_SD_participants_per_target_word = 
  semanticpriming %>% group_by(target_word) %>% 
  summarise(length(unique(Participant))) %>% 
  select(2) %>% unlist %>% sd %>% sprintf('%.2f', .)

```

- `r semanticpriming_number_participants` participants

- `r semanticpriming_number_target_words` target words

- `r nrow(semanticpriming) %>% formattable::comma(digits = 0)` observations

- `r semanticpriming_mean_target_words_per_participant` target words per participant (*SD* = `r semanticpriming_SD_target_words_per_participant`)

- `r semanticpriming_mean_participants_per_target_word` participants per target word (*SD* = `r semanticpriming_SD_participants_per_target_word`)

---

- Lexical decision = overt task

Over multiple trials, do the characters form a real word?

--

- Semantic priming = covert experimental design

>  <span style='color:blue;'> PRIME WORD  &nbsp; &nbsp;  target word</span>

>  &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; PIKE  &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;  prack

---

- Primes always real words; targets sometimes nonwords

  - Lexical decision on the target word (i.e., word or nonword?)


- Prime word: 150 ms

--

Interstimulus interval: 50 or 1,050 ms

Target word: until response or 3,000 ms

--

Linguistic information usually more influential than visual information 

<div class='p-3 mb-2 bg-light text-dark' style='background-image: var(--bs-gradient);'>(Lam et al., 2015; Petilli et al., 2021)</div>

---

# Main effects (2/2)

# model_table() is a custom function from the 'R_functions' folder
semanticpriming_maineffects_2 =
  
  # model_table() is a custom function from the 'R_functions' folder
  model_table(KR_summary_semanticpriming_lmerTest,
              confidence_intervals = confint_semanticpriming_lmerTest,
              select_effects = c('Word-concreteness difference',
                                 'Cosine similarity <sup>a</sup>',
                                 'Visual-strength difference <sup>a</sup>',
                                 'Interstimulus interval <sup>a</sup>'),
              caption = '') %>%
  
  # Group predictors under headings
  pack_rows('Semantic variables', 1, 3) %>% 
  pack_rows('Task condition', 4, 4) %>% 
  
  # Highlight covariates
  row_spec(1, background = '#EFEFEF') %>%
  
  footnote(general_title = 'Note. ', 
           general = "Shaded rows contain covariates. Variables involving 'difference' or 'similarity' are based on the comparison of the prime and the target words in each trial.",
           alphabet = c('By-participant random slopes were included for this effect.'),
           footnote_as_chunk = TRUE) %>%
  
  kable_classic(full_width = F, html_font = 'Cambria')


# Interactions (1/2)

# (Nakagawa et al., 2017; https://doi.org/10.1098/rsif.2017.0213). 
# Also, transform coefficient to rounded percentage.

Nakagawa2017_fixedeffects_R2_semanticpriming_lmerTest = 
  paste0(
    (MuMIn::r.squaredGLMM(semanticpriming_lmerTest)[1, 'R2m'][[1]] * 100) %>% 
      sprintf('%.2f', .),
    '%')

Nakagawa2017_randomeffects_R2_semanticpriming_lmerTest = 
  paste0(
    (MuMIn::r.squaredGLMM(semanticpriming_lmerTest)[1, 'R2c'][[1]] * 100) %>% 
      sprintf('%.2f', .),
